episode.title: American Textile Mfrs. Institute, Inc. v. Donovan

turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
turn.label: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger
turn.text: We will hear arguments first this morning in American Textile Manufacturers Institute v. The Secretary of Labor, and National Cotton Council v. The Secretary of Labor; consolidated cases.
Mr. Bork, you may proceed whenever you are ready.

turn.speaker: robert_h_bork
turn.label: Mr. Robert H. Bork
turn.text: Mr. Chief Justice and may it please the Court:
These cases are here on writ of certiorari from the Court of Appeals for the District of Columbia.

That Court upheld a health standard promulgated by the Occupational Safety and Health Administration, and the standard specifies the maximum amount of respirable cotton dust that may be in the air of any textile plant.
It is intended to reduce the incidence of byssinosis, which is a respiratory condition associated with cotton dust.
Petitioner in one case are... American Textile Manufacturers Association or ATMI, a trade association, and 12 manufacturer members.
Petitioners in the other case are the National Cotton Council, which represents all seven segments of the cotton industry from farmers to textile manufacturing.

The standard is extraordinarily severe and costly; it requires textile manufacturers to reduce cotton dust within four years to.2 milligrams per cubic meter of air in all yarn manufacturing processes and to.75 milligrams per cubic meter in all weaving processes.
Now this standard was arrived at by OSHA by applying their carcinogen policy, which this Court remembers from Benzene.
The Benzene case requires that the exposure limit be set at the lowest feasible level.
It is ironic that just two days ago OSHA rescinded its carcinogen policy.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: Mr. Bork, how do you define the word feasible in that statute?

turn.speaker: robert_h_bork
turn.label: Mr. Robert H. Bork
turn.text: Well in a variety of ways, Justice Rehnquist.
In the first place, my first point will be that, to find a standard economically feasible, OSHA must have an estimate of costs which is based upon substantial evidence.
It must then find what those costs mean to the industry, what impact it will have upon the industry; how many jobs, how much investment will be lost because of that cost.
And finally, it has to have a legal criteria by which it is able to state that the impact it finds is economically feasible.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: And did you draw that definition from the Congressional language or legislative history?

turn.speaker: robert_h_bork
turn.label: Mr. Robert H. Bork
turn.text: From the Congressional language and also it seems to me, Justice Rehnquist, that it is impossible to say that something is feasible without knowing what it will do to the industry.
And OSHA has made no finding here of what it will do to the industry other than to say that some undefined number of plants may close.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: Well, and that the industry as such would not go... not cease to exist?

turn.speaker: robert_h_bork
turn.label: Mr. Robert H. Bork
turn.text: The industry as such, Justice Stewart, will not cease to exist is all they have said.
That finding is thoroughly consistent with 90 percent of the industry being left, or 50 percent of the industry being left, or 10 percent of the industry being left.
In fact, the literal language that OSHA uses would be satisfied if there were a single mil left.
That standard of the industry will continue to exist is not a standard at all.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: But it is the one that OSHA applied?

turn.speaker: robert_h_bork
turn.label: Mr. Robert H. Bork
turn.text: That's the only one, that's right, Justice Stewart.

And one of our contentions is that that standard, if that is considered to be a standard, means that nobody knows what OSHA is doing; judicial review is impossible, and you have the completely uncanalized power over industry that this Court found improper on the benefit side of the act.
Here, they are claiming the same power through their power to impose costs without limit, or without any real limit.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: Well Mr. Bork, if while the Benzene case was pending here, the Board had revoked its carcinogen policy, as you say it now has, would we have remanded that Benzene case for reconsideration?

turn.speaker: robert_h_bork
turn.label: Mr. Robert H. Bork
turn.text: I trust so.
Because--

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: And are you suggesting that that should be done here?

turn.speaker: robert_h_bork
turn.label: Mr. Robert H. Bork
turn.text: --I'm suggesting that, but I have additional suggestions, Justice White--

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: Yes, I know you do.
But this is a very recent development, I take it?

turn.speaker: robert_h_bork
turn.label: Mr. Robert H. Bork
turn.text: --Monday.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: Is there anything official--

turn.speaker: robert_h_bork
turn.label: Mr. Robert H. Bork
turn.text: I believe it's in the Federal Register as of Monday, is it not?

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: --Have the parties given us anything, Mr. Bork?

turn.speaker: robert_h_bork
turn.label: Mr. Robert H. Bork
turn.text: No, I just learned about it last night.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: I haven't heard it until you just mentioned it.
Well could, I know you have other points but it's possible that would be dispositive--

turn.speaker: robert_h_bork
turn.label: Mr. Robert H. Bork
turn.text: I think it is, Justice White.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: --Mr. Bork, can you hypothesize the circumstances in which a major industry, producing things we regard as necessary, that is, the entire automobile industry and the entire lumber industry, the entire cotton industry... can you hypothesize any situation in which it could be simply closed down and stopped, by operation of law?

turn.speaker: robert_h_bork
turn.label: Mr. Robert H. Bork
turn.text: You mean that it would be proper to do it that way?

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: Could it be done that way?

Could the Congress of the United States, through its mechanisms such as we have here, in effect say, no more automobiles shall be produced because automobiles kill 63,000 people a year and injure two million people a year, and therefore.

turn.speaker: robert_h_bork
turn.label: Mr. Robert H. Bork
turn.text: I think, Mr. Chief Justice, that I would agree that the Congress does have the power to do that.
There may be problems about compensation, but I think it has the power to do that.
However, one thing is clear; that Congress in the OSHA act did not intend just to shut down industries, because they required that the standard be economically feasible.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: Mr. Bork, the Chief Justice asked you if the Congress could through its technicians, accomplish this result?
My understanding of the act was that Congress had delegated to the executive branch the accomplishment of these particular results.
I don't know if your answer would be any different if the question were phrased in those terms or not.

turn.speaker: robert_h_bork
turn.label: Mr. Robert H. Bork
turn.text: Well, I think an additional problem arises, Justice Rehnquist, and that is the problem that Congress did not delegate the power to destroy an industry because it specifically required that economic feasibility be present.
So while Congress may have the raw constitutional power to do that, it is perfectly clear that in this statute it has not done that.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: Well, one of your points is that there was an overdelegation, in the sense that it's... a delegation without any standards, isn't it?

turn.speaker: robert_h_bork
turn.label: Mr. Robert H. Bork
turn.text: That is quite correct, Justice White.
But it is more than that, because it is a constitutional point in that sense.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: Right.

turn.speaker: robert_h_bork
turn.label: Mr. Robert H. Bork
turn.text: But it is also a statutory point, so that--

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: Right.

turn.speaker: robert_h_bork
turn.label: Mr. Robert H. Bork
turn.text: --I think those persons who do not think that the delegation doctrine remains a part of constitutional law would nevertheless wish to reverse here, for a wholly inadequate set of findings about economic feasibility.
One simply cannot judge economic feasibility in any way from the record OSHA has made.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: The statutory word is feasible, isn't it?

turn.speaker: robert_h_bork
turn.label: Mr. Robert H. Bork
turn.text: Pardon me?

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: The statutory word is feasible, I mean, not economically feasible?

turn.speaker: robert_h_bork
turn.label: Mr. Robert H. Bork
turn.text: That is correct.
Everybody who has looked at it, every Court who has looked at it has accepted the contention that feasibility requires both technological feasibility and economic feasibility.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: And maybe some other kind of feasibility.

turn.speaker: robert_h_bork
turn.label: Mr. Robert H. Bork
turn.text: Perhaps so.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: And along with the executives, along with OSHA, they think it includes economic--

turn.speaker: robert_h_bork
turn.label: Mr. Robert H. Bork
turn.text: Yes they do... no, OSHA does not contend that economic feasibility is not a requirement.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: --Right.
But the statutory standard is feasible.

turn.speaker: robert_h_bork
turn.label: Mr. Robert H. Bork
turn.text: That is correct, Justice Stewart.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: Mr. Bork, could I be sure I understand your suggestion about the revocation of... OSHA's carcinogen policy?
I didn't understand... this is not a carcinogen that we're dealing with here, is it?

turn.speaker: robert_h_bork
turn.label: Mr. Robert H. Bork
turn.text: That's why I find it ironic that OSHA continues to insist upon a standard arrived upon the carcinogen policy for cotton dust which is not a carcinogen.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: Well, but did they expressly rely on their carcinogen policy here, or do you think their reasoning was--

turn.speaker: robert_h_bork
turn.label: Mr. Robert H. Bork
turn.text: As I understand it--

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: --comparable to that used in the other cases?

turn.speaker: robert_h_bork
turn.label: Mr. Robert H. Bork
turn.text: --It was certainly identical, not just comparable, Justice Stevens.
And I think they expressly relied upon it.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: Was the lead case in this same Court of Appeals?

turn.speaker: robert_h_bork
turn.label: Mr. Robert H. Bork
turn.text: Yes.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: Is that a carcinogen or is it more akin to this?

turn.speaker: robert_h_bork
turn.label: Mr. Robert H. Bork
turn.text: The lead case is... the carcinogen policy was amended because of the Benzene case, and they said that the... that lowest, that carcinogen policy requiring the lowest feasible level was inconsistent with the act.
I would suppose this is too.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: My question was the lead case, in this same Court of Appeals?

turn.speaker: robert_h_bork
turn.label: Mr. Robert H. Bork
turn.text: Yes.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: Was that like this, a non-cancer-producing agent?
Or was it a cancer-producing agent?

turn.speaker: robert_h_bork
turn.label: Mr. Robert H. Bork
turn.text: No, it is not a carcinogen.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: Wasn't the reason for revoking the carcinogen policy, at least as applied in cases like Benzene, was the failure to make a finding that was made in this case, namely that there was a significant risk.
So does revocation really affect this case?

turn.speaker: robert_h_bork
turn.label: Mr. Robert H. Bork
turn.text: Well, I don't think the... I'll come to that, I don't think the significant risk--

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: You don't contest the fact there was such a... the finding required by Benzene was made here, I don't think you dispute that?

turn.speaker: robert_h_bork
turn.label: Mr. Robert H. Bork
turn.text: --That first finding was, yes.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: Yes, and you don't challenge it as being adequately supported by the record?

turn.speaker: robert_h_bork
turn.label: Mr. Robert H. Bork
turn.text: Well there is a significant risk in cotton dust, it's a question of at what level and with what controls that risk disappears, is very much before us.
But my first point I have,... really want to argue two propositions.
The first one is economic feasibility.
And as to that, my point is that three things are required.
As I said, an estimate of costs based upon substantial evidence.
Our point here is that the estimate of costs is based upon no evidence, it is pure conjecture.
But the second two elements of economic feasibility aren't even present here, and that is, what do those costs mean for the industry, how much of this industry is going to be destroyed.
That isn't even addressed here, except to say the whole industry won't be destroyed.

And thirdly, there is no criteria of any sort; no policy judgment, no articulated policy judgment, nothing as to why whatever percentage of the industry is going to be destroyed should nevertheless be considered a feasible policy.
So that, two of the three elements which are inherent and inevitable in any finding of economic feasibility simply aren't present here, and that fact alone, I think, requires reversal.
Additionally, there is no substantial evidence to support the cost for the bases, so that we have economic feasibility requiring three elements, not one of which is present in this case.

And the government's brief I think, quite understandably, attempts to obscure this point which is present in our main brief, by speaking as if we are only arguing about the substantial evidence supporting the cost estimate.
We are not only arguing that.
We are also arguing that the other two elements which are required for any sensible judgment of economic feasibility aren't even addressed at this point.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: Well, Mr. Bork, none of this, I gather, as you've now stated, involves an argument that a cost benefit analysis was obtained?

turn.speaker: robert_h_bork
turn.label: Mr. Robert H. Bork
turn.text: That is my second proposition, Justice Brennan.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: That's your second point.

turn.speaker: robert_h_bork
turn.label: Mr. Robert H. Bork
turn.text: And these--

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: Is that under the feasibility or under the reasonably necessary?

turn.speaker: robert_h_bork
turn.label: Mr. Robert H. Bork
turn.text: --I think it's under both, Justice Brennan.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: Under both.

turn.speaker: robert_h_bork
turn.label: Mr. Robert H. Bork
turn.text: Under both sections of the statute.
But I want to stress that these two propositions are logically independent.

The argument about economic feasibility would in and of itself justify reversal, quite aside from whether there was any requirement, which we contend there is, that there be a reasonable relationship between costs and benefits.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: And were these points presented this way to the Court of Appeals?

turn.speaker: robert_h_bork
turn.label: Mr. Robert H. Bork
turn.text: The Court of Appeals, the cost-benefit point was presented and the finding of economic feasibility was attacked, yes.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: But in these terms, in the terms that you are now putting... with the three elements?

turn.speaker: robert_h_bork
turn.label: Mr. Robert H. Bork
turn.text: I don't think it was that drawn out, in quite that sharp a form.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: You're inferring that the Court of Appeals dealt with these particular points?

turn.speaker: robert_h_bork
turn.label: Mr. Robert H. Bork
turn.text: No.
The Court of Appeals simply accepted the idea that if... which was challenged... that if the whole industry was not destroyed, that was sufficient.
The Court of Appeals articulated that standing.
But I think therefore, under the economic feasibility point, that the agency is claiming an unfettered power--

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: Mr. Bork, can I ask you what you... for a little clarification of the second point in your three points that are required?
How much of the industry must be destroyed before it's no longer feasible?

Supposing that... say the figure is 25 percent and supposing 25 percent of the firms would go out of business but the remaining 75 percent would be able to expand their production and continue to produce the same aggregate amount of goods.
Would that be feasible or not feasible under your standard?

turn.speaker: robert_h_bork
turn.label: Mr. Robert H. Bork
turn.text: --Well, in the first place, Justice Stevens, I am not advancing any standard because I am not in a position to do so.
These things have never been addressed--

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: No, but you are advancing a proposition that there must be measurement of the percentage of the industry destroyed.
What do you mean by destroying industry, is that to mean destroying existing firms or a portion of the total output?

turn.speaker: robert_h_bork
turn.label: Mr. Robert H. Bork
turn.text: --Oh, I think it means both.

For example, if... it may be that if there is a section of the country where all of the firms would be destroyed with drastic effects upon employment and so forth and so on, that might be considered not feasible, even though the production would shift to a different section of the country.
But I don't really wish to settle that.
We haven't... this is a process of developing this law which has not even been gone through by OSHA.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: It's just not there.

turn.speaker: robert_h_bork
turn.label: Mr. Robert H. Bork
turn.text: Pardon me?

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: It's just not there.

turn.speaker: robert_h_bork
turn.label: Mr. Robert H. Bork
turn.text: It's just not there.
And I am really not prepared to spell out all of the conditions under which--

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: Would you say OSHA is free to pick whatever approach to the word feasible makes sense, as long as it follows these three criteria?

turn.speaker: robert_h_bork
turn.label: Mr. Robert H. Bork
turn.text: --That's true.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: Because certainly there's no Congressional guidance on this precise point.

turn.speaker: robert_h_bork
turn.label: Mr. Robert H. Bork
turn.text: No, that's true.

I think the... while we're talking about practical concerns and so forth... I think it would be a common law development when OSHA began to give the reasons why it found a certain level of destruction feasible.
The Courts could then look at it and we would begin to get some rationality into OSHA's processes and we would know what they were doing.
And not least, that would make OSHA politically accountable to Congress, because Congress would know then what price we are paying for this kind of thing.
So I think it is a large function of this Court to introduce political accountability into processes, governmental processes, which lack them.
And this one certainly lacks them.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: Let me pursue the hypothetical question I put to you earlier, Mr. Bork.
In your view, would Congress have the constitutional authority to bar cigarettes, for example, unless they can demonstrate that all negative health factors were eliminated?
Could Congress do that itself via statute?

turn.speaker: robert_h_bork
turn.label: Mr. Robert H. Bork
turn.text: In my opinion, you have chosen the example, Mr. Chief Justice, that pains me a great deal, but I think they could.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: Second question: could they delegate that, by a structure somewhat like the usual pattern of creating a commission like OSHA, could they delegate that to a commission on tobacco hazards?

turn.speaker: robert_h_bork
turn.label: Mr. Robert H. Bork
turn.text: I think, again, Mr. Chief Justice, the answer is yes they could, if they told the agency what it was to consider in arriving at the conclusion whether or not cigarettes were to be banned.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: That is, do you mean by that if the commission, after hearings, made findings that it had this definite health hazard factor, carcinogen-producing elements, then the commission could--

turn.speaker: robert_h_bork
turn.label: Mr. Robert H. Bork
turn.text: I think so, if it's a canalized, structured delegation, so the commission isn't just roaming free.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: --And it would have nothing to do with... or Congress would not be limited by the fact that this would put a great many people out of business?

turn.speaker: robert_h_bork
turn.label: Mr. Robert H. Bork
turn.text: No, Congress would not be, nor would OSHA, if they had been delegated the task.

But they were delegated the task to do it to the extent that it is feasible, which we all, I think agree that it means economically feasible, and given that, I think they have to make the findings that go to feasibility.
And they have not.
Now the other point--

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: Mr. Bork, before you proceed, does OSHA agree with your assertion that it has authority, under the act, to put 50 percent of a major industry out of business?

turn.speaker: robert_h_bork
turn.label: Mr. Robert H. Bork
turn.text: --Justice Powell, the difficulty is that OSHA has never addressed what it's authority is.
I think... well, I don't know--

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: Are OSHA's findings in the papers that we have before us?
I couldn't locate them.

turn.speaker: robert_h_bork
turn.label: Mr. Robert H. Bork
turn.text: --OSHA's findings are simply that the entire industry will not be destroyed or industry as a whole will not be destroyed, that's all they said.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: And I'm sure the Solicitor General will respond to my question, but one of the examples you gave was that... I understood it, that under the standard before us in this case 90 percent of the industry could be put out of business and OSHA would still claim the standard was appropriate.

turn.speaker: robert_h_bork
turn.label: Mr. Robert H. Bork
turn.text: OSHA could still claim, under that form of words.
I don't know what OSHA would do in that case.
And a large part of OSHA's argument in its brief is that they don't really need to state a standard because they are very reasonable and prudent people.
And in effect, the brief argues, you can certainly trust us because we're reasonable and we're careful.
But that's the--

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: Did OSHA make the sort of findings of fact that we expect from a trial court, and if so, where are they?

turn.speaker: robert_h_bork
turn.label: Mr. Robert H. Bork
turn.text: --I can't find them, Justice Powell.
I think it's an extraordinarily vague performance.
We don't know what they mean about feasibility, which is my entire point.
The... they did say, that some marginal plants will close rather than comply.
One, if marginal means plants that are close to the edge financially, that could be a very large part of the industry.
We don't know.
Some plants will close rather than comply, other plants may go out of business after they try to comply.
OSHA simply has not addressed that issue.
In a way, I think they have to, to have a rational process that can be reviewed by anybody.
The only thing they have tried to do, is state that they have found particular costs.
I think I will have to provide that subject in view of the time, because if a careful look is taken at their cost estimates it will be found that they rest upon nothing.

For example, in the spinning process, which is one of the most expensive to deal with in terms of getting dust levels down, it turns out that their own contractor, RTI, found 553 million dollars to get down to the.2 level OSHA insists upon, and said that local exhaust would be necessary; local exhaust ventilation.

Now it turns out, you can't put local exhaust ventilation on spinning frames, and the experts Hocutt and Thomas, who were our dust control experts, said it couldn't get down to.2 under any circumstances.
OSHA did two things: it made up its own technology, both experts agreed, you had to do it by local exhaust ventilation.
OSHA just decided no, you can do it some other way; we don't know how they think we can do it, except they speak vaguely about room ventilation, which the people agree won't work.
They also made up their own cost figures.

They rejected their own contractors' cost figures by about 500 million dollars, so that we... the one thing we do know about the cost that OSHA projects is that they have no relationship to the real costs.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: Are respirator masks a guarantee of protection, Mr. Bork?

turn.speaker: robert_h_bork
turn.label: Mr. Robert H. Bork
turn.text: They are not, Your Honor.
They may be used by some people, but not by others, and in cases where they may not be used, cannot be used, then transferred to a--

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: But where they are used, are they a guarantee?

turn.speaker: robert_h_bork
turn.label: Mr. Robert H. Bork
turn.text: --As I understand it, yes, Mr. Chief Justice.
Now--

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: What is the factor that renders them unfeasible?

turn.speaker: robert_h_bork
turn.label: Mr. Robert H. Bork
turn.text: --Well for some people, the standard sizes don't fit.
Some people have a little trouble breathing through them, other people can use them.
So you have to try it on the individual and see whether he is one who can use it.
One more point about costs which is simply that, I think it is quite clear that less cotton is going to be manufactured as a result of this standard.
In fact, the cotton production has been dropping every year since the standard was announced.

And OSHA decided it did not have to look at the costs imposed, for example, upon cotton farmers; there are 160,000 cotton farmers many of whom are no longer going to growing cotton and OSHA just simply ignored all of those costs in its standard and didn't even address them.
Which, I think, is also improper.
But I'd like to turn to the second proposition now, which is the question of whether there has to be a reasonable relationship between costs and benefit.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: Before you go on to that, Mr. Bork, is there anything in this record that would indicate that with dropping domestic production of cotton and cotton products--

turn.speaker: robert_h_bork
turn.label: Mr. Robert H. Bork
turn.text: The National Cotton... I'm sorry.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: --that there are imports that are taking up the slack?

turn.speaker: robert_h_bork
turn.label: Mr. Robert H. Bork
turn.text: That is correct, Mr. Chief Justice.

The National Cotton Council put in the evidence on what would happen to cotton farmers, it put in the evidence upon the decline of domestic cotton production which I think is about 2.5 percent a year for the last four years, and of course, the import of domestic, foreign textiles, cotton-made textiles, has been increasing and may increase at 6 to 7 percent a year, even under the restrictive trade agreements.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: Anything to prevent Congress from, or OSHA, from providing that no imports would be permitted in this country unless the sources complied with OSHA's standards?

turn.speaker: robert_h_bork
turn.label: Mr. Robert H. Bork
turn.text: Nothing that I can think of, Mr. Chief Justice.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: But, how would we, as a practical matter, how would we--

turn.speaker: robert_h_bork
turn.label: Mr. Robert H. Bork
turn.text: How would we effect it?

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: --Yes, would we send inspectors over to--

turn.speaker: robert_h_bork
turn.label: Mr. Robert H. Bork
turn.text: Well, I addressed your question on the assumption that Congress has the raw power to try it.
I don't think it's a very practical effort.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: --That would take treaties.

turn.speaker: robert_h_bork
turn.label: Mr. Robert H. Bork
turn.text: It would, it would.
But on the relationship between cost and benefit, I think this is an ideal case to consider it, because--

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: Excuse me for interrupting you again, Mr. Bork, we're not giving you much chance, I'm afraid.
But, in connection with your argument, I gather what you're now addressing is a little different than the costs discussion you've been giving us as to unfeasibility--

turn.speaker: robert_h_bork
turn.label: Mr. Robert H. Bork
turn.text: --It's entirely different.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: --it is independent, isn't it?

turn.speaker: robert_h_bork
turn.label: Mr. Robert H. Bork
turn.text: That's right.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: The cost benefit?
Now isn't cost benefit analysis a... that's an expression of art, isn't it, some kind of--

turn.speaker: robert_h_bork
turn.label: Mr. Robert H. Bork
turn.text: No, Justice Brennan, I think it is what we all do every day, and in about every decision we make.
And OSHA has been doing cost benefit analysis when they chose to go after cotton dust before noise, when they chose a.2 level and chose a.75 level for other processes, they did it because they--

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: --Well, yet, what we're concerned with here, I gather, is what the relationship is of cost to benefit, and how do you define benefit here?

turn.speaker: robert_h_bork
turn.label: Mr. Robert H. Bork
turn.text: --We define benefit in what additional worker health protection will be provided by the--

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: Production of the PEL, is that it?

turn.speaker: robert_h_bork
turn.label: Mr. Robert H. Bork
turn.text: --Well, that's not a benefit, unless it provides additional protection to workers.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: From this... cost question?

turn.speaker: robert_h_bork
turn.label: Mr. Robert H. Bork
turn.text: That's right, and here I think the real case to be decided... the reason I think this is a case that's almost ideal for this kind of discussion, is that byssinosis is not a carcinogen, it develops slowly, it can be caught by a variety of tests long before it gets to the irreversible stage, so that I think there is no benefit, but I don't have to say that... I think there's no benefit, to reducing the PEL from.5 to.2 when you have a medical surveillance plan which catches these things and the workers can be transferred or put in respirators.

But at least OSHA should have addressed the question, whether moving from... down from.5 to.2....5 is a reduction in dust levels, I mean, that's our proposal, whether coming down from.5 to.2 with a medical surveillance plan which OSHA itself has said these tests would insure that any significant change from the baseline determination will become apparent before material impairment occurs.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: Well even if you are right, where in the statute is the requirement that OSHA do what you're now suggesting OSHA should have done?

turn.speaker: robert_h_bork
turn.label: Mr. Robert H. Bork
turn.text: I think this comes under the reasonably necessary language, and under the requirement of feasibility, and indeed, it comes I think from the language that OSHA's counsel seem to think goes the other way, which is no material impairment of health to the extent feasible.

That isn't a standard about, that isn't a criteria about a single health hazard, that is the worker and the total amount of risks he faces in the marketplace, and you can't come close or as close as is possible--

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: Well, I guess we'd all be better off if Congress had said in express terms that OSHA should have done a cost benefit-analysis.
What kind do you suggest?

turn.speaker: robert_h_bork
turn.label: Mr. Robert H. Bork
turn.text: --Justice Brennan, I would stress that I'm not suggesting a computer or a slide rule and a straight weighing.
I think OSHA should be allowed... required, is required to state what range it is dealing with in cost-benefits--

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: Well are we going to... if they must do a cost-benefit analysis, are we not going to have to define what we mean by cost-benefit analysis?

turn.speaker: robert_h_bork
turn.label: Mr. Robert H. Bork
turn.text: --In the sense that you want OSHA to articulate the... because they have never done it, the additional benefits from.5 with medical surveillance to.2 with medical surveillance, and I think there are no additional benefits.
But they've never articulated it if there are any.

And I don't think this is reading something into the statute in any heroic fashion, Justice Brennan, because this is a less heroic reading of the statute than, for example, reading the rule of reason was into the Sherman Act, whose text simply doesn't allow the rule of reason.
But in order to make that a rational and useful statute, rather than a wholly destructive statute, this Court read the rule of reason in it.
So, here, I think the text of this statute easily allows and indeed, compels the finding that... and I want to stress this, OSHA says in its brief, that it is comparing all these factors.
So it's not resisting thinking about cost-benefit.
On page 57, they give you a list of all the cost-benefit analyses they do, what they are resisting is disclosing their thought processes.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: Spelling it out.

turn.speaker: robert_h_bork
turn.label: Mr. Robert H. Bork
turn.text: That's right.
So that anybody, Justice Marshall, can review it, or find out what they're talking about, or so that Congress can find out what they're talking about and what kind of--

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: Mr. Bork, do you think they can do it in a meaningful way without putting a value on human life?

turn.speaker: robert_h_bork
turn.label: Mr. Robert H. Bork
turn.text: --Certainly, Justice Stevens.

In the first place, I would stress that human life is not at stake in this case, because at the levels we're talking about and the medical surveillance we're talking about, this stuff can be caught before it becomes irreversible and human life is not at stake in this case, nor is material impairment of health at stake in this case.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: Well, would it not have to put a dollar value on the irreversible stage of the disease at least?

turn.speaker: robert_h_bork
turn.label: Mr. Robert H. Bork
turn.text: Not in this case, Justice Stevens, and not in most cases, I think.
Not a dollar value.
But... and nobody expects that.
We expect them to state... we expect the following benefits, they're going to cost so much, and that seems to us reasonable--

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: But one side of the equation is all measured in dollars.

turn.speaker: robert_h_bork
turn.label: Mr. Robert H. Bork
turn.text: --But we're not asking, Justice Stevens, that they come up and say, look, the benefits in dollars outweigh the costs in dollars.
What we want is an articulation of what they expect to get for how much money, and over time, they will develop a common law and Courts will begin to understand what--

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: So, to that extent, I gather, what you're suggesting is judgmental?

turn.speaker: robert_h_bork
turn.label: Mr. Robert H. Bork
turn.text: --It is judgmental.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: The ultimate conclusion has to be judgmental.

turn.speaker: robert_h_bork
turn.label: Mr. Robert H. Bork
turn.text: It is.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: But not in dollar terms, based on the benefits?

turn.speaker: robert_h_bork
turn.label: Mr. Robert H. Bork
turn.text: No.
That is correct, absolutely correct.
We don't expect that kind of analysis at all.

But if their process is to be rational, and if we are to know that it's rational... if industry is to know, if the Courts are to know, if the Congress is to know, I think they ought to spell out what it is they expect to get for how much money.
Here,--

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: You think the statute requires that they do so?

turn.speaker: robert_h_bork
turn.label: Mr. Robert H. Bork
turn.text: --That is correct, Justice Stewart.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: And is it your further contention that if the statute doesn't require they should do so, that the statute, there may be constitutional doubts about the statute itself?

turn.speaker: robert_h_bork
turn.label: Mr. Robert H. Bork
turn.text: I would think so, because at that point we don't know what OSHA is doing.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: A successive delegation standard for this delegation--

turn.speaker: robert_h_bork
turn.label: Mr. Robert H. Bork
turn.text: At that point it is, at that point.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: --Unless the statute requires them to do what you indicated?

turn.speaker: robert_h_bork
turn.label: Mr. Robert H. Bork
turn.text: I think so.

Of course, the alternative strategy, Justice Stewart, is to help them develop the criteria to save the statute, rather than striking it down; or to interpret the statute so that it is done to avoid that constitutional problem.
But I don't think we're asking anything peculiar, or anything they don't say they're doing; we are asking that they tell us what they are doing, that's all.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: One final question, if I may, Mr. Bork.

Do you contend that this is a toxic substance case under Section 6, or whatever the number is, do you contend there is any difference in the cost-benefit analysis in a toxic substance case than in any other standards?

turn.speaker: robert_h_bork
turn.label: Mr. Robert H. Bork
turn.text: No, I don't think so, in that sense.
Because this is not, there are toxic substances that produce harm that can't be reversed.
I think that's a very different case, than this case where, despite some confusions upon the topic--

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: Well, we've got to decide which section of the statute we're working with, and Section 6, where the word feasibility is found, is in the toxic substance section.
Do you... first of all, do you agree that that's the appropriate section for purposes of statutory analysis?

turn.speaker: robert_h_bork
turn.label: Mr. Robert H. Bork
turn.text: --I think--

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: Assuming it's a toxic substance.

turn.speaker: robert_h_bork
turn.label: Mr. Robert H. Bork
turn.text: --I think Section 6 is the appropriate section, but I think all standards are also governed by Section 3.8.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: So that if, if they are governed by 3.8, and that's the source of the cost-benefit requirement, then I don't think you can rely on the word feasibility.

turn.speaker: robert_h_bork
turn.label: Mr. Robert H. Bork
turn.text: No, I rely, Justice Stevens, on both of those sections.
It seems to me that both 3.8 and--

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: But you can't rely on both if it's not a toxic substance case, and that's why it seems to me we've got to think through the question whether the rule is different for a toxic substance than it is for a non-toxic substance.

turn.speaker: robert_h_bork
turn.label: Mr. Robert H. Bork
turn.text: --Well, we agree it is a toxic substance.
And it seems to me that if one wants to discuss 6(b)(5) alone, that the requirement of a cost-benefit comparison, and articulation of reasons, is to be found in 6(b)(5).

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: Well no, my point is somewhat different.
My point is, when one is confronted with a non-toxic substance and therefore doesn't have the benefit of the language in 6(b)(5), is there also a cost-benefit requirement.
And if so, that requirement is found independently of the feasibility language.

turn.speaker: robert_h_bork
turn.label: Mr. Robert H. Bork
turn.text: That's right, I think it would be found, Justice Stevens, in the reasonably necessary language of the section.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: If that's enough, then you can't really rely on the feasibility language.
Seems to me you're in somewhat of a dilemma and I don't know what the right answer is, but I--

turn.speaker: robert_h_bork
turn.label: Mr. Robert H. Bork
turn.text: I confess, Justice Stevens, at the moment I don't quite perceive the dilemma I'm in.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: --Well if the reasonably necessary language requires cost-benefit analysis for all standards, then we don't even have to look at the feasibility language.

turn.speaker: robert_h_bork
turn.label: Mr. Robert H. Bork
turn.text: That's right.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: On the other hand, if you must look at the feasibility language in order to justify or to support your argument that cost-benefit is appropriate, then you do not require cost-benefit in non-toxic substance cases, which would be somewhat ironic, because that would mean that you have a more strict standard, the agency has a stricter burden, in the toxic substance case than in the non-toxic substance case.

turn.speaker: robert_h_bork
turn.label: Mr. Robert H. Bork
turn.text: Well Justice Stevens, if I may ask, it would seem to me, and perhaps I'm wrong, that if it was a toxic substance case you can derive it and should derive it from 6(b)(5) to the extent feasible.
If it is a non-toxic substance case, it seems to me it can be derived and should be derived from the language that a standard must be one which is reasonably necessary or appropriate.
Is that... am I still in a dilemma?

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: Well I think you are, but I won't take up any more of your time, because--

turn.speaker: robert_h_bork
turn.label: Mr. Robert H. Bork
turn.text: My time is gone, Justice Stevens.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: --It seems to me that the... that one has to decide whether Congress intended a different standard for toxic substances than it did for non-toxic substances.
Having made that decision, then one must decide which portions of the statute will support your argument.

turn.speaker: robert_h_bork
turn.label: Mr. Robert H. Bork
turn.text: I do not think that Congress provided cost-benefit for toxic substances alone.
It seems to me it's a general requirement of the act.

turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
turn.label: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger
turn.text: Very well.
Mr. Geller.

turn.speaker: kenneth_s_geller
turn.label: Mr. Kenneth S. Geller
turn.text: Thank you, Mr. Chief Justice, and may it please the Court:
The textile industry has presented two main challenges to the cotton dust standard in this case.
The first is the cost-benefit issue, second is the factual claim that the administrative record does not support the Secretary's findings of economic feasibility.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: Excuse me, Mr. Geller, are you going to address this development of a couple of days ago?

turn.speaker: kenneth_s_geller
turn.label: Mr. Kenneth S. Geller
turn.text: I'd be happy to.
I was just about to do it.
I wanted to say about the second part of Petitioner's argument, the substantial evidence, that we think the Court of Appeals correctly analyzed that factual question.
But I do want to point out that Professor Bork is incorrect in saying that the cotton dust standard was issued pursuant to any sort of carcinogen policy.
It doesn't... it was not at all.
It was issued pursuant to substantial evidence of a significant health risk at the current exposure level.
The pre-standard current exposure level.
There were 105,000 pages of record in this case, and they pointed conclusively to a substantial risk of material health impairment at the 1,000 microgram level.

Dr. Merchant produced a dose-response curve, it was not subject to serious challenge at the administrative hearing, showed that at that level 26 percent of the workers would be exposed to some risk of byssinosis.
Also showed that at the level that the Secretary proposed that risk would be cut in half, to 13 percent.

There's no question in this case we think, both that the Secretary satisfied the Benzene standard, and that he issued the standard pursuant to substantial evidence of the significant health risk that the standard would reduce, not pursuant to any so-called policy.
This is just another industry red herring.
Now Professor Bork made another... a number of other misstatements about the record that are purely factual.
I want to just mention them very briefly.
The answers are all in our brief.
I don't think it's very useful here to replay the evidentiary disputes that the Secretary resolved and that the Court of Appeals found were supported by substantial evidence.
The respirators are not feasible, the record quite clearly shows that.
Secondly, the industry's approach in this case, and certainly the basis for the so-called ATMI alternative was this notion that the low-grade of byssinosis were no more damaging than the common cold.
That's absolutely incorrect.
There was substantial evidence in the record of material health risk even at low levels of byssinosis, and more important, the Secretary found that it's a continuum of disease.
Dr. Harley, the industry's main witness, testified that byssinosis is a continuum of disease, but it doesn't progress in a rational fashion.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: Is it possible to tell from OSHA's announcements in this case what it understands feasible to be, to mean?

turn.speaker: kenneth_s_geller
turn.label: Mr. Kenneth S. Geller
turn.text: Yes, well, the Secretary has always taken the position--

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: Is it something more than affordable?

turn.speaker: kenneth_s_geller
turn.label: Mr. Kenneth S. Geller
turn.text: --It means economically affordable by the industry as a whole, not by every individual employer in the industry.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: So what... just as long as it's affordable by the industry as a whole?

turn.speaker: kenneth_s_geller
turn.label: Mr. Kenneth S. Geller
turn.text: That's right.
That it won't materially impair the industry's financial condition, industry will be able to maintain long-term competitiveness and profit levels.
And here, the Secretary found, the industry as a whole will not be threatened by the capital requirements of the regulation, that's page 27378.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: Well, do you mean by that, that if the record showed that compliance would increase the cost of cotton to the ultimate consumer by 500 percent, that then we could go ahead?

turn.speaker: kenneth_s_geller
turn.label: Mr. Kenneth S. Geller
turn.text: No, because in that situation--

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: You didn't put any limit on the economic feasibility in your earlier statement.

turn.speaker: kenneth_s_geller
turn.label: Mr. Kenneth S. Geller
turn.text: --Well, it would not be feasible if people would no longer buy cotton, the industry would go out of business.
But in this case--

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: Well, that would depend upon the elasticity of the--

turn.speaker: kenneth_s_geller
turn.label: Mr. Kenneth S. Geller
turn.text: --Well that's right, and the Secretary went into all of that.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: --finding that it was an absolutely inelastic demand, and it could be increased 1000 percent--

turn.speaker: kenneth_s_geller
turn.label: Mr. Kenneth S. Geller
turn.text: Well perhaps then if the costs--

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: --amount of purchasing.

turn.speaker: kenneth_s_geller
turn.label: Mr. Kenneth S. Geller
turn.text: --And if the costs could all be passed along to the consumers, the consumers would still be able to buy, would still buy the product, then the health costs are the cost of doing business.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: Are you suggesting that Congress contemplated that the whole country wait until we find out whether it's going to make the cost go up 1000 or 500 percent?

turn.speaker: kenneth_s_geller
turn.label: Mr. Kenneth S. Geller
turn.text: Well the Secretary has the burden of proving economic feasibility, he does... he does analyses, in this case, for example, the evidence showed that there would be a decrease in demand for cotton of only about 1 or 2 percent under the Secretary's proposed standard, and that costs could rise to keep the same profit levels, only--

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: Mr. Geller, you refer to the word... the phrase that the Secretary has the burden of proving economic feasibility, as I recall, the statute simply says if feasible, doesn't it?

turn.speaker: kenneth_s_geller
turn.label: Mr. Kenneth S. Geller
turn.text: --That's correct.
Feasibility though, is a requirement before Section 6(b)(5)--

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: Well why do you read the word economic into it?

turn.speaker: kenneth_s_geller
turn.label: Mr. Kenneth S. Geller
turn.text: --Well, I think that I agree with Professor Bork and certainly with the lower court, that Section 6(b)(5) has construed the word feasible to mean both technologically and economically feasible.
That's what we think Congress meant.

That's... in other statutes, such as the Clean Air Act which was passed the same week as the Occupational Safety and Health Act, Congress specifically said economically and technologically feasible, and in this statute, that's--

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: But wouldn't that be almost an argument against your position, if Congress the same week, when using the word feasible, had modified it with the words economic and technologically, and in this statute it simply said if feasible--

turn.speaker: kenneth_s_geller
turn.label: Mr. Kenneth S. Geller
turn.text: --Well I don't think, Congress doesn't act in computer-like fashion, but I think that when in the same week they used the word feasible and define it to mean both economic and technological feasibility, that that's what they mean when they... the same week, used the word feasible without the modifiers.
There's no suggestion in very lengthy legislative history, Mr. Justice Rehnquist, that they meant anything other than economic or technological feasibility.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: --Incidentally, Mr. Geller, you just mentioned pass the cost on to the consumer, was there any finding to that effect?

turn.speaker: kenneth_s_geller
turn.label: Mr. Kenneth S. Geller
turn.text: Yes, there were substantial--

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: Well, I know there was an extreme assumption, I think that's the language, but what was the supporting evidence that it could be passed on or would be?

turn.speaker: kenneth_s_geller
turn.label: Mr. Kenneth S. Geller
turn.text: --There was testimony by experts in the field that--

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: No well, I'm asking, what finding other than the expression extreme assumption?

turn.speaker: kenneth_s_geller
turn.label: Mr. Kenneth S. Geller
turn.text: --No, no, no.

There were express findings in this case, Mr. Justice Brennan, in cent per profit cent, how much each garment would go up, these are all of course speculations, but informed ones, OSHA did not talk in vague generalities.

The preamble to this standard takes up some 40 or 50 pages of three column, small type in the Federal Register, justifying every single finding that the Secretary made, and the Court of Appeals took 100 pages analyzing the record very carefully to conclude that the Secretary's findings as regard to these Petitioners were supported by substantial evidence.

The... anyway, I just want to mention another one of the misstatements I think that was made, because I think it's important, the Secretary does not engage in the cost-benefit analysis under Section 6(g), he sets priorities, by statute he sets priorities.
And it didn't take very much sophistication for the Secretary to realize that the number one priority facing the textile industry in terms of health was cotton dust.
He didn't engage in any cost-benefit analysis to make that decision; it was obvious it--

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: Well, you instinctively do, as Professor Bork suggested.
Every decision that every person or institution makes is instinctively or implicitly inherently... a cost-benefit decision.

turn.speaker: kenneth_s_geller
turn.label: Mr. Kenneth S. Geller
turn.text: --Not with the same set of--

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: Even in the setting of priorities.

turn.speaker: kenneth_s_geller
turn.label: Mr. Kenneth S. Geller
turn.text: --Yes, but not, I don't think, Mr. Justice Stewart, with the same sort of mathematical precision that these Petitioners are going to require--

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: Whether or not you're going to play an extra rubber of bridge, you weigh the pleasure of playing an extra rubber of bridge with the loss of sleep that's going to be incurred.
Every decision that's made is a cost-benefit decision, is it not?
Every rational decision?

turn.speaker: kenneth_s_geller
turn.label: Mr. Kenneth S. Geller
turn.text: --Every rational decision takes into account costs and benefits, perhaps, but it doesn't weigh them the way the Petitioners suggest the Secretary has to weigh them in some sort of fine balance in this case.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: In the setting of priorities, it's a cost-benefit decision.

turn.speaker: kenneth_s_geller
turn.label: Mr. Kenneth S. Geller
turn.text: And the Secretary does that under Section 6(g), and therefore there's no reason to think that when the standard is issued, that under Section 6(g) and under Section 6(b)(5), and under Section 3(8), that it's going to be irrational.
Let me also mention--

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: Mr. Geller, Mr. Bork mentioned the fact that there were no findings and I can't find any findings.
Now will you tell me where they are?

turn.speaker: kenneth_s_geller
turn.label: Mr. Kenneth S. Geller
turn.text: --The findings are in the preamble to the standard which is published in Volume 43 of the Federal Register.
We have supplied--

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: I'm talking about the findings in this case.

turn.speaker: kenneth_s_geller
turn.label: Mr. Kenneth S. Geller
turn.text: --Yes, that's what I'm talking about.
The Federal Register contains--

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: Well, do you want us to go read that, to take judicial notice of that?

turn.speaker: kenneth_s_geller
turn.label: Mr. Kenneth S. Geller
turn.text: --It's in the Federal Register and we have supplied a copy to every Justice of this Court, that these are the Secretary's findings to justify the standard.
And the Court of Appeals found that each of those findings, with regard to these Petitioners, was supported by substantial evidence.
I don't understand--

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: Well what finding did they make on economic feasibility?
What was the quote and end-quote finding?

turn.speaker: kenneth_s_geller
turn.label: Mr. Kenneth S. Geller
turn.text: --Well, the discussion of economic feasibility is at page 27378, Federal Register, and the key finding that was backed up by a great deal of evidence and cost figures, is that industry as a whole will not be threatened by the capital requirements of the regulation.
That these cost--

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: Do you know of any other case that we've decided that we didn't have papers we were deciding it on?

turn.speaker: kenneth_s_geller
turn.label: Mr. Kenneth S. Geller
turn.text: --I'm not quite sure what you're referring to, Mr. Justice Marshall.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: We're referring to what's in the Federal Register and is not in this Court.

turn.speaker: kenneth_s_geller
turn.label: Mr. Kenneth S. Geller
turn.text: Well--

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: Period.

turn.speaker: kenneth_s_geller
turn.label: Mr. Kenneth S. Geller
turn.text: --Let me also address the statement that Mr. Justice Stevens was making to Professor Bork at the very end, about Section 3(8)--

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: Before you do that, I think just as a matter of mechanics, I don't recall ever seeing the copy of the decision that is... the findings that you say are in the Federal Register and were supplied to each of us individually; I don't think they were.

turn.speaker: kenneth_s_geller
turn.label: Mr. Kenneth S. Geller
turn.text: --Well,--

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: I frankly assumed they were in the Joint Appendix--

turn.speaker: kenneth_s_geller
turn.label: Mr. Kenneth S. Geller
turn.text: --No, they were not... reprinted in the Joint Appendix, but they are in the Federal Register which is of course a public document, and we did supply, or we sent it up to the Clerk... I'm surprised it hasn't been distributed with the cover letter.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: --Well I don't think it was.

turn.speaker: kenneth_s_geller
turn.label: Mr. Kenneth S. Geller
turn.text: It's all, it's easily accessible to the Court.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: I don't have it before me... saving money by not putting it in the Appendix?

turn.speaker: kenneth_s_geller
turn.label: Mr. Kenneth S. Geller
turn.text: It's... the Federal Register, June 23rd, 1978, Federal Register, beginning at page 27350 and I'm sure the Clerk will be happy to--

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: Does it look like what you have in your hands?

turn.speaker: kenneth_s_geller
turn.label: Mr. Kenneth S. Geller
turn.text: --Yes it does, it's--

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: I've never seen it.

turn.speaker: kenneth_s_geller
turn.label: Mr. Kenneth S. Geller
turn.text: --I'm sorry, Your Honor.
We sent that up about 10 days ago.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: Does that comply with our rules with respect to type size and page... pagination?

turn.speaker: kenneth_s_geller
turn.label: Mr. Kenneth S. Geller
turn.text: Well I'm not sure that we had an obligation under the rules to reprint all of this, it would have been very burdensome.
We thought it would be useful for the Court, rather than simply to have the Court go to the library to get a public document, that we give Xerox copies.
We understand... the Petitioner's of course, had the burden of producing the Appendix, and not the Respondents.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: Which if any of the questions presented by the Certiorari petition do you think raise a question that requires us to decide whether there's substantial evidence to support a finding?

turn.speaker: kenneth_s_geller
turn.label: Mr. Kenneth S. Geller
turn.text: I think the way that this case was argued in the Court of Appeals was that there was no substantial evidence to support the economic feasibility argument.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: I didn't ask you about how the case was argued in the Court of Appeals--

turn.speaker: kenneth_s_geller
turn.label: Mr. Kenneth S. Geller
turn.text: And I think that is one of the questions presented in the petition that the Court granted certiorari on.
The Court did not grant certiorari on one of the four questions, which just went to whether the Court of Appeals in fact applied a substantial evidence test.
I'd like to spend my limited time discussing what I think is the key issue in the case, which is the cost-benefit issue.
It's become something of a rallying cry for industry forces in this area.

Simply stated, Petitioners claim that the Secretary may not issue an Occupational Health Standard for toxic substances till he first determines, on the basis of substantial evidence, that the benefits of the standard bear a "reasonable relationship" to the attendant costs.
I think it's important to begin this discussion by repeating what the Court said just a month ago in the Crushed Stone case.
That is that the question here is not what the Court thinks is generally appropriate to the regulatory process.
Congress is, the question is what Congress intended.
We've heard a great deal from the textile industry, both in its briefs and from Professor Bork today, about wise policy choices.
The issue here--

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: --Congress didn't say anything about cost-benefit analysis, did it?

turn.speaker: kenneth_s_geller
turn.label: Mr. Kenneth S. Geller
turn.text: --It did not, and that is our point, that there is, that the construction statute adopted by the Court of Appeals we think, reflects wise policy, but that's not the point.
The point is that there's nothing in the statute, either expressly or by reasonable implication that requires the Secretary to engage in so-called cost-benefit analysis before issuing a health--

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: Well was there anything in the statute then, that sets any standards at all?

turn.speaker: kenneth_s_geller
turn.label: Mr. Kenneth S. Geller
turn.text: --Yes, there is.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: And if the answer to that is no there isn't, then, is my brother Rehnquist's opinion in the Benzene case, is a telling one.

turn.speaker: kenneth_s_geller
turn.label: Mr. Kenneth S. Geller
turn.text: If, I think that if Justice Rehnquist were right about the statute, he would be right about his conclusions.
But the statute sets criteria that the Secretary has to follow.

There is first of all, Section 6(b)(5), which says that the Secretary can't issue any standard unless he first finds that there's a significant risk of material health impairment in the work place, that it's an unsafe work place.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: Well, but the... there, as we held in Benzene, misconstrued that requirement.

turn.speaker: kenneth_s_geller
turn.label: Mr. Kenneth S. Geller
turn.text: And that the standard would substantially reduce that risk.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: Well those were... that's what was involved in the Benzene case.

turn.speaker: kenneth_s_geller
turn.label: Mr. Kenneth S. Geller
turn.text: That's right, that's right.
That's a substantial--

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: In which we had to correct the misapprehensions of OSHA.

turn.speaker: kenneth_s_geller
turn.label: Mr. Kenneth S. Geller
turn.text: --That is a substantial check on the Secretary now, he can't issue--

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: Well it wasn't understood by OSHA to be any check at all, until the Benzene case, isn't that correct?

turn.speaker: kenneth_s_geller
turn.label: Mr. Kenneth S. Geller
turn.text: --I don't want to re-argue the Benzene case--

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: Well of course you don't.

turn.speaker: kenneth_s_geller
turn.label: Mr. Kenneth S. Geller
turn.text: --but, be happy to if I thought the result might change.

But, the point is that in light of Section 3(8) as construed by this Court in Benzene, the Secretary now in issuing health standards, has to find that there's a significant risk of material health impairment and his standard will reduce that risk.
He also has to find that it's technologically and economically feasible.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: Mr. Geller, I'd like to come back with a question that I put to Professor Bork, is it the government's position that this standard would be perfectly valid under the act if it destroyed 50 percent of the cotton industry in the United States, whether you measure it by number of companies or by total output, was that the government's position?

turn.speaker: kenneth_s_geller
turn.label: Mr. Kenneth S. Geller
turn.text: It's not the government's position, but--

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: Suppose 10 percent, would that--

turn.speaker: kenneth_s_geller
turn.label: Mr. Kenneth S. Geller
turn.text: --Well, the one thing that I agree with Professor Bork about, is that these are not issues that can be decided in the abstract.
The economic feasibility determination is that basic factual determination by the Secretary--

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: --Yes, but--

turn.speaker: kenneth_s_geller
turn.label: Mr. Kenneth S. Geller
turn.text: --with judicial review--

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: --Yes, but what troubles me and perhaps others, is that we're not getting any guidance, at least I've found none so far in this case, as to what the impact of... economically speaking, you admit that that's important... in view of the competition that our industry, our major industries are now suffering from industries in foreign countries, I would have thought OSHA would have taken a better, closer look, to ascertain whether 50, 20, 25, 45 percent of the cotton industry was going to be put out of business.

turn.speaker: kenneth_s_geller
turn.label: Mr. Kenneth S. Geller
turn.text: --Well, but the Secretary did make findings in this case, Justice Powell.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: Where are they, specifically?

turn.speaker: kenneth_s_geller
turn.label: Mr. Kenneth S. Geller
turn.text: Well, I think, once again, page 27378 is the prime discussion of this issue.

The Secretary found that only certain marginal employers, very close to the margin... first of all, the Secretary found that there was a concentration process going on in this industry, wholly regardless of health standards, that firms at the margin, because of economies of scale or other reasons, were simply not making it and going out of business.
It's not a very heavily concentrated industry by the way, by and large.
There are--

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: Mr. Geller, did the Secretary consider in these findings that we haven't seen, whether these standards would materially affect the capability of the industry to modernize and expand and improve its production facilities?

turn.speaker: kenneth_s_geller
turn.label: Mr. Kenneth S. Geller
turn.text: --Yes.
Yes, he did.
He found that there was great excess capacity in the industry as it was, there was not going to be a great deal of expansion going on--

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: But we have excess capacity in the steel industry, but it's suffering from competition for more modern facilities in Japan and Germany.
I just don't know whether OSHA considered or considers that the act requires it to weigh factors of this kind.

turn.speaker: kenneth_s_geller
turn.label: Mr. Kenneth S. Geller
turn.text: --Yes, it does.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: It does?

turn.speaker: kenneth_s_geller
turn.label: Mr. Kenneth S. Geller
turn.text: It does, and OSHA must consider, in making the economic feasibility determination, the industry's capital needs, the industry's costs of doing business.

And it has to determine if, by adding to those costs, the costs of the proposed standard, the industry as a whole will be able to function much the same way it was functioning prior to the issuance of the standard.
It's no suggestion that the Secretary thinks that the way to solve health problems is to take away the productive activity that causes the health problems.
The purpose is to try to reach some reasonable accommodation.
The word feasibility does that, and I think the other standards of the statute do that.

Let me, I do want to address this one question that Justice Stevens asked Professor Bork about Section 3(8) because I think it's an important question in the Court's determination of the answer to this case.

That is, that Section 3(8) could not have been thought to have any cost-benefit analysis in it, because if you recall, Section 3(8) was a definitional section, it was in the statute in precisely the same form it exists today from the very beginning, and yet, Senators Dominick and Senator Javits and others were quite concerned during the latter stages of the legislative history, that the statute might require absolute hell for spending a lot of money for things that weren't worth it, and they restructured Section 6(b)(5) to take account of that, by adding the feasibility language and material health language and all the rest, there would have been no reason for them to have engaged in that discussion if anybody thought that a cost-benefit analysis was already in the reasonably necessary or appropriate phrase in Section 3(8).
But nobody suggested that, during a length of an exceedingly lengthy legislative history, not one person suggested that 3(8) meant that.
Section 3(8)--

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: Well there wasn't really any discussion of cost-benefit as such, was there?

turn.speaker: kenneth_s_geller
turn.label: Mr. Kenneth S. Geller
turn.text: --That's... no one suggested that the statute was going to require that, that's exactly right.
And that's why we think it's totally--

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: The discussion was whether this was some sort of an absolute requirement?

turn.speaker: kenneth_s_geller
turn.label: Mr. Kenneth S. Geller
turn.text: --And there would have been no need for that discussion if someone thought that Section 3(8) already imposed a cost-benefit analysis in setting standards.
Section 3(8) tells the Secretary when he may issue a standard, it doesn't tell him where along the various alternatives he should issue--

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: Do you think this raises no delegation questions under Schechter and other cases?

turn.speaker: kenneth_s_geller
turn.label: Mr. Kenneth S. Geller
turn.text: --No, I don't, Mr. Chief Justice.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: And your time doesn't permit you to go beyond that,--

turn.speaker: kenneth_s_geller
turn.label: Mr. Kenneth S. Geller
turn.text: I'd be happy to answer, but--

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: --you're in your colleague's time now.

turn.speaker: kenneth_s_geller
turn.label: Mr. Kenneth S. Geller
turn.text: --Thank you.

turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
turn.label: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger
turn.text: Mr. Cohen.

turn.speaker: george_h_cohen
turn.label: Mr. George H. Cohen
turn.text: Mr. Chief Justice, and may it please the Court:
My name is George Cohen, I'm appearing on behalf of the Union Respondents.

Although I'm not sure this is the point to put the proper focus on it, I would like to point out to Mr. Justice Powell that, in response to your questions, Your Honor, that the Research Triangle Institute studies which were the contractor working for the Department of Labor at Joint Appendix pages 118, 120 and 123, discuss precisely the question that Your Honor raised, and basically concluded that insofar as achieving the costs necessary to achieve the standard that the Secretary set, the demand, the total demand for cotton products in this country would go down approximately one percent, and the impact on employment would be approximately.6 percent.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: Mr. Cohen, excuse me.
No, go ahead.
What is your definition of the word if feasible, in the statute?

turn.speaker: george_h_cohen
turn.label: Mr. George H. Cohen
turn.text: Mr. Justice Rehnquist, the words of the statute are to the extent feasible, there's a bit of deja vu in this, because we do this together in the Benzene case, our... my answer then and my answer today, as further enlightened by this Court's decision in Benzene, is that the Congress of the United States was not seeking to impose impossible, impossible health... a solution that would be impossible as far as industry would be concerned, and that impossibility has been translated into two dimensions.
Number one, that it must be achievable in the sense that there is the technology and work place practices available, so-called technologically feasible.
The economic feasibility aspect which has also been imported into the statute, is in essence what this case... or what--

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: Well, imported into the statute by this Court, or by--

turn.speaker: george_h_cohen
turn.label: Mr. George H. Cohen
turn.text: --No, I don't think it's been imported into the statute by this Court, I think Senator Dominick--

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: --You mean yet.

turn.speaker: george_h_cohen
turn.label: Mr. George H. Cohen
turn.text: --Well, I thought the question, Mr. Justice Marshall, was does the origin of the importing come out of this Court?

I think the answer to that is no, I think this Court properly concluded that the legislative history as reflected most precisely by Senator Dominick, the leading spokesman for the Nixon Administration as this bill was passing through the halls of Congress, who made it very clear that what he was most concerned about... and this then became the consensus of the Senatorial concern, was that in the name of providing safety and health what would happen would be that you would drive industries as a whole out of business and ban occupations as a whole in the course of that process.
And it was that concern, whether one wants to then put in terms the word economic, feasibility which I am perfectly comfortable with and all the reviewing Courts have used, and this Court--

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: And OSHA, and OSHA.

turn.speaker: george_h_cohen
turn.label: Mr. George H. Cohen
turn.text: --And OSHA, yes.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: And that feasible includes economically feasible, everybody agrees?

turn.speaker: george_h_cohen
turn.label: Mr. George H. Cohen
turn.text: Yes, everybody agrees there.
The question, among the questions presented here is in order for something to be feasible, must this magical cost-benefit analysis be done, we of course reject that argument.
We reject it because we say, number one, it's not there on the face of the statute, and number two, it is not there in the legislative history.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: What do you mean by cost-benefit analysis?
What do you think the other side means by it?

turn.speaker: george_h_cohen
turn.label: Mr. George H. Cohen
turn.text: Mr. Justice White, I must confess that the more one studies this issue the less, I think, one comprehends it.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: Well then you are very... so far, what you have said is meaningless.
And so--

turn.speaker: george_h_cohen
turn.label: Mr. George H. Cohen
turn.text: Well I--

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: --apparently then, what your opposition is saying, you think, is meaningless?

turn.speaker: george_h_cohen
turn.label: Mr. George H. Cohen
turn.text: --I do that, yes.
And I'll be glad to, I'll be glad to explain why.
